content.raw:
Yes, ```blocked``` is ```true```. But this situation is ok. We use this variable to control the behaviour of class. In test I check that the return value of ```wait``` was ```false``` and ```blocked``` was ```true``` and the opposite situation.

What do you think?
content.html:
Yes, blocked is true. But this situation is ok. We use this variable to control the behaviour of class. In test I check that the return value of wait was false and blocked was true and the opposite situation.

content.raw: `Blocked()` should tell us whether the watcher is blocked or not. This is a public method and the behavior should be clear. If we agree on that, why `Blocked()` should return `true` if someone calls it after a `wait_until()` that times out? The thread is not blocked at that point, right?

1) With this string: All old tests work correct, but the logic for current task is broken. I added two tests in test/integration/twoProcessesPubSub.cc file: WaitForSubscribersSameTypeNamesRemoteSubscribers and WaitForSubscribersDifferentTypeNamesRemoteSubscribers. In these cases I want to have remote subscriber in NodeShared::remoteSubscribers. Then I want to check this block in Node::WaitForSubscribers():

  // Remote subscribers. Check message type names.
  if (hasRemoteSubscribers)
  {
    for (const auto &proc : subscribers)
    {
      const auto &v = proc.second;
      for (const auto &subscriber : v)
      {
        if (subscriber.MsgTypeName() == _typeName)
          return true;
      }
    }
  }

It works good.

2) Without this string: I check that message types are different and I do not have a remote subscriber.

Could you specify what should I describe more, please?

content.raw:
I think we should keep the line. That line executes on the subscriber side. This function is running when the discovery discovers a new topic. Then, we check if we have a local subscriber on that topic. If we have it, we have to check that the types match. If so, we send a message to the control address of the publisher to notify that we are a new remote subscriber. I haven't debug it but I think that we should be able to check that the types match here.

In the integration tests, `waitForSubscribers_aux` subscribes using a callback with type `ignition::msgs::Vector3d`. On the file `twoProcessesPubSub`, in both of your tests you're advertising with a different type. In that case I would say that there's no real remote subscriber, right? This seems like the correct behavior. We should try a third case where we advertise an `ignition::msgs::Vector3d` message, then we should see the remote subscriber.

Does it make sense?
content.html:
I think we should keep the line. That line executes on the subscriber side. This function is running when the discovery discovers a new topic. Then, we check if we have a local subscriber on that topic. If we have it, we have to check that the types match. If so, we send a message to the control address of the publisher to notify that we are a new remote subscriber. I haven't debug it but I think that we should be able to check that the types match here.

In the integration tests, waitForSubscribers_aux subscribes using a callback with type ignition::msgs::Vector3d. On the file twoProcessesPubSub, in both of your tests you're advertising with a different type. In that case I would say that there's no real remote subscriber, right? This seems like the correct behavior. We should try a third case where we advertise an ignition::msgs::Vector3d message, then we should see the remote subscriber.

Does it make sense?

1. I retrieved this line in commit [dd3e7b2]. I agree with you it is better to check the type here. Could you write a test case (maybe in issue tracker) to cover this behaviour (it is important to have this type check on subscriber side), please?
  2. There are also tests with the same types. In the test twoProcPubSub.WaitForSubscribersSameTypeNamesRemoteSubscribers the program checks the remote subscriber. The remote subscriber exists and it checks in Node::WaitForSubscribers. The test twoProcPubSub.WaitForSubscribersDifferentTypeNamesRemoteSubscribers has different types. With this line if (handler.second->TypeName() != _pub.MsgTypeName()) the check in Node::WaitForSUbscribers:
        // Remote subscribers. Check message type names.
        if (hasRemoteSubscribers)
        {
          for (const auto &proc : subscribers)
          {
            const auto &v = proc.second;
            for (const auto &subscriber : v)
            {
              if (subscriber.MsgTypeName() == _typeName)
                return true;
            }
          }
        }

is redundant. Is it better to remove this check?

content.raw:
1. Your test `WaitForSubscribersDifferentTypeNames` is exercising that line, no need to create an additional test. You can test it with:


```
#!c++

./test/integration/INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPubSub --gtest_filter="*WaitForSubscribersDifferentTypeNames"
```
If you modify the code to print a message or debug it with `gdb`, you should observe that the condition `handler.second->TypeName() != _pub.MsgTypeName()` is `true` and the `NodeShared` does not send a message to the control address of the publisher (which is the correct behavior).
content.html:
1. Your test WaitForSubscribersDifferentTypeNames is exercising that line, no need to create an additional test. You can test it with:
./test/integration/INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPubSub --gtest_filter="*WaitForSubscribersDifferentTypeNames"

If you modify the code to print a message or debug it with gdb, you should observe that the condition handler.second->TypeName() != _pub.MsgTypeName() is true and the NodeShared does not send a message to the control address of the publisher (which is the correct behavior).

I think is still needed. The first part of WaitForSubscribers() guarantees that your node has advertised the topic before with the requested type (type1 for example). This part checks whether there are already remote subscribers. We need it because other node within our process could advertise the same topic but different type (type2 for example) and other node in a separate process might be subscribed using type2 too. In this scenario, we'll have a remote subscriber for our topic but we're not interested on it because our type is type1. We should create a test case for this scenario:

reset();

transport::Node node;
transport::Node node2;
unsigned int timeout = 1000;
EXPECT_TRUE(node.Advertise<ignition::msgs::Vector3d>(g_topic));
EXPECT_TRUE(node2.Advertise<ignition::msgs::Int32>(g_topic));

std::string subscriberPath = testing::portablePathUnion(
   PROJECT_BINARY_PATH,
   "test/integration/INTEGRATION_waitForSubscribers_aux");
testing::forkHandlerType pi = testing::forkAndRun(subscriberPath.c_str(),
  partition.c_str());
std::this_thread::sleep_for(std::chrono::milliseconds(timeout));

EXPECT_FALSE(node2.WaitForSubscribers<ignition::msgs::Vector3d>(g_topic,
  timeout));

testing::waitAndCleanupFork(pi);

This test is for this check:

if (pub.MsgTypeName() != _typeName)
{
    std::cerr << "Node::WaitForSubscribers() Type mismatch." << std::endl
        << "\t* Type advertised: " << pub.MsgTypeName() << std::endl
        << "\t* Type published: " << _typeName << std::endl;
    return false;
}

I think we can not have the situation for this block:

if (subscriptionHandlerPtr->TypeName() == _typeName)
    return true;

Sorry, I meant a test similar to this one:

transport::Node node;
transport::Node node2;
unsigned int timeout = 1000;

EXPECT_TRUE(node2.Advertise<ignition::msgs::Vector3d>(g_topic));
EXPECT_TRUE(node.Advertise<ignition::msgs::Int32>(g_topic));

std::string subscriberPath = testing::portablePathUnion(
   PROJECT_BINARY_PATH,
   "test/integration/INTEGRATION_waitForSubscribers_aux");
testing::forkHandlerType pi = testing::forkAndRun(subscriberPath.c_str(),
  partition.c_str());

EXPECT_FALSE(node.WaitForSubscribers<ignition::msgs::Int32>(g_topic,
  timeout));

And this other test should trigger the condition if (subscriptionHandlerPtr->TypeName() == _typeName):

transport::Node node;
transport::Node node2;
unsigned int timeout = 1000;

EXPECT_TRUE(node2.Subscribe(g_topic, cb));
EXPECT_TRUE(node.Advertise<ignition::msgs::Int32>(g_topic));

std::string subscriberPath = testing::portablePathUnion(
   PROJECT_BINARY_PATH,
   "test/integration/INTEGRATION_waitForSubscribers_aux");
testing::forkHandlerType pi = testing::forkAndRun(subscriberPath.c_str(),
  partition.c_str());

EXPECT_TRUE(node.WaitForSubscribers<ignition::msgs::Int32>(g_topic,
  timeout));

content.raw:
How about if we make this method templated? Something like this:

`template <typename T> bool WaitForSubscribers(const std::string &_topic, const int _timeout = INT_MAX);`

I think it's more elegant to provide a protobuf message type, instead of a string. The string is just what we use internally as the message type. I feel this is more consistent with other methods (`Advertise()`, `Subscribe()`) too.

This forces to move the implementation to the header file. Internally you can declare a local variable of type `T` and call `GetTypeName()` to get the string type. What do you think?
content.html:
How about if we make this method templated? Something like this:

template <typename T> bool WaitForSubscribers(const std::string &_topic, const int _timeout = INT_MAX);

I think it's more elegant to provide a protobuf message type, instead of a string. The string is just what we use internally as the message type. I feel this is more consistent with other methods (Advertise(), Subscribe()) too.

This forces to move the implementation to the header file. Internally you can declare a local variable of type T and call GetTypeName() to get the string type. What do you think?

I have an implementation problem. There is a line std::string nodeUuid = this->dataPtr->nUuid; in Node::WaitForSubscriber(). I have a compiler error:

/home/user/code/issue_47_wait/include/ignition/transport/Node.hh:991:45: error: invalid use of incomplete type ‘class ignition::transport::NodePrivate’
         std::string nodeUuid = this->dataPtr->nUuid;
                                             ^
/home/user/code/issue_47_wait/include/ignition/transport/Node.hh:62:11: error: forward declaration of ‘class ignition::transport::NodePrivate’
     class NodePrivate;

How can I use nUuid?

content.raw: This is because we cannot access a member variable of NodePrivate from Node.hh. NodePrivate is suppose to be accessible only from Node.cc. Take a look at [PIMPL pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opaque_pointer). Instead, use `this->NodeUuid()`.
content.html: This is because we cannot access a member variable of NodePrivate from Node.hh. NodePrivate is suppose to be accessible only from Node.cc. Take a look at PIMPL pattern. Instead, use this->NodeUuid().

  // Create a transport node and advertise a topic.
  ignition::transport::Node node;

  auto pubId = node.Advertise<ignition::msgs::StringMsg>(topic);
  auto pubId1 = node.Advertise<ignition::msgs::Int32>(topic);
  if (!pubId)
  {
    std::cerr << "Error advertising topic [" << topic << "]" << std::endl;
    return -1;

    std::cerr << "Error advertising topic [" << topic << "]" << std::endl;

  // Prepare the message.

  msg.set_data("HELLO");
  msg1.set_data(12);

  // Publish messages at 1Hz.

content.raw:
I have a problem with `cmdTopicPub()` function in `ign.cc`. I can call WaitForSubscribers:

```
#!c++

node.WaitForSubscribers(_topic, msg->GetTypeName(), 800);
```

In this case

```
#!c++

node.WaitForSubscribers<msg->GetTypeName()>(_topic, 800);
```
there is an error:

```
#!bash

/usr/include/c++/4.9/bits/basic_string.h:112:11: note: ‘std::basic_string<char>’ is not literal because:
     class basic_string
           ^
/usr/include/c++/4.9/bits/basic_string.h:112:11: note:   ‘std::basic_string<char>’ has a non-trivial destructor
/home/user/code/issue_47_wait/src/ign.cc:170:62: error: no matching function for call to ‘ignition::transport::Node::WaitForSubscribers(const char*&, int)’
       node.WaitForSubscribers<msg->GetTypeName()>(_topic, 800);
                                                              ^
/home/user/code/issue_47_wait/src/ign.cc:170:62: note: candidate is:
In file included from /home/user/code/issue_47_wait/src/ign.cc:33:0:
/home/user/code/issue_47_wait/include/ignition/transport/Node.hh:960:41: note: template<class T> bool ignition::transport::Node::WaitForSubscribers(const string&, int)
       public: template<typename T> bool WaitForSubscribers(




```

I created two API functions like `Advertise()`. How can I call `WaitForSubscribers` correctly?

       public: template<typename T> bool WaitForSubscribers(

I created two API functions like Advertise(). How can I call WaitForSubscribers correctly?

content.raw:
`msg->GetTypeName()` returns a `std::string` value and the template parameter needs to be a protobuf type, not a string (e.g.: `ignition::msgs::Int32`). This is why you see the error.

I believe you can get a type from a variable at compilation time doing `decltype(my_var)`. However, in this case it's not as easy because the return value of `ignition::msgs::Factory::New()` is a pointer to a generic `google::protobuf::Message`, not the derived type.

~~Leave it as it's because this is kind of hard to solve and out of the scope of this pull request.~~

Well, per issue #54, we now know that we shouldn't have more than one type per topic advertised within the same node. So, I believe there's no need to use a template anymore (in fact, the message type shouldn't be a parameter anymore, we can internally get the type). If we remove it, we'll solve this issue, right? Sorry for all these changes.
content.html:
msg->GetTypeName() returns a std::string value and the template parameter needs to be a protobuf type, not a string (e.g.: ignition::msgs::Int32). This is why you see the error.

I believe you can get a type from a variable at compilation time doing decltype(my_var). However, in this case it's not as easy because the return value of ignition::msgs::Factory::New() is a pointer to a generic google::protobuf::Message, not the derived type.

Leave it as it's because this is kind of hard to solve and out of the scope of this pull request.

Well, per issue #54, we now know that we shouldn't have more than one type per topic advertised within the same node. So, I believe there's no need to use a template anymore (in fact, the message type shouldn't be a parameter anymore, we can internally get the type). If we remove it, we'll solve this issue, right? Sorry for all these changes.

content.raw: I think that it takes some time to solve issue#54, so we decided to do issue#54 in a different pull request, but add different types support here. Do you prefer to add different types later (maybe never) and now use `WaitForSubscribers` as simple as possible?
content.html: I think that it takes some time to solve issue#54, so we decided to do issue#54 in a different pull request, but add different types support here. Do you prefer to add different types later (maybe never) and now use WaitForSubscribers as simple as possible?

content.html: Let's go for the easier version for now.

content.raw: Could you move this block after the `std::unique_lock<std::recursive_mutex> lk(this->Shared()->mutex);`? There's risk of race condition here.
content.html: Could you move this block after the std::unique_lock<std::recursive_mutex> lk(this->Shared()->mutex);? There's risk of race condition here.

content.raw: I do not understand why it is important here. Here I use function for current instance of class: `this->`. In `Node::AdvertisedTopics()` function I see the mutex `std::lock_guard<std::recursive_mutex> lk(this->dataPtr->shared->mutex);`. I think it will be double check.
content.html: I do not understand why it is important here. Here I use function for current instance of class: this->. In Node::AdvertisedTopics() function I see the mutex std::lock_guard<std::recursive_mutex> lk(this->dataPtr->shared->mutex);. I think it will be double check.
